original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. This is why our dreams can have special meanings that are not just simple words.

original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Carol Dweck is a psychologist who says our brain can change and we can get better at things we are not good at first. Many people praise others for what they are naturally good at, like saying "You are really good at paying attention to details" or "You are great at organising parties". But research shows that it's better to praise how people do things, like saying "You tried really hard" or "You found a good way to solve this problem". This helps people learn new things and get even better at what they can already do.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Psychologist Carol Dweck, who supports the idea of a "growth mindset," says the brain can change and grow. This means we can learn new skills, even if we’re not good at them at first. Many people praise results or natural talent, like saying, “You’re so good at noticing small things” or “You’re a natural at planning events.” But studies show it’s better to praise how someone works—like their effort, trying new ways, or solving problems. This kind of praise helps people keep improving and developing their skills.

If we praise effort, trying new things, and finding solutions to problems, people are more likely to learn and improve. This helps them develop new skills and get even better at things they already do well.

original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: A psychologist named Carol Dweck from Stanford University did an experiment with 10-year-old kids. She gave them problems that were a bit too difficult. Some kids were happy to try and said they enjoyed the challenge. They believed they could get better with practice. Dweck calls this a "growth mindset", which means they think about what they can do in the future. On the other hand, some kids felt bad because they thought they weren't smart enough and had failed. They had a "fixed mindset", which means they thought their abilities wouldn't change. Some of these kids said they might cheat next time, while others looked for someone who did worse to feel better about themselves.

At the start of her work, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave a group of ten‑year‑old children tasks that were a little too hard.  

One group liked the challenge. They said they enjoyed trying and believed they could get better with practice. This is called a **growth mindset** – the idea that you can improve your abilities in the future.  

The other group felt the test said they were not smart enough and that they had failed. They thought their ability could not change. This is called a **fixed mindset** – the idea that you cannot improve your abilities.  

Some children in this group said they might cheat later. Others tried to find someone who did worse than them so they would feel better about themselves.

However, another group felt they were being tested on how smart they were and thought they had failed. These kids had a "fixed mindset," meaning they didn't think they could improve. Some said they might cheat in the future, while others tried to find someone who did worse to feel better about themselves.

Carol Dweck called this way of thinking a "growth mindset."

But another group of children felt bad. They thought the hard problems meant they were not smart enough. They believed they could not get better, no matter how hard they tried. But another group of children felt that someone was testing how smart they were and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' - this means they believe they cannot change or get better. original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: When we watch the news, it can seem like the world is becoming a more violent place. But there are some positive things to think about too. After World War II, there were many wars that killed a lot of people - 30 wars killed more than 100,000 people. Now, countries are generally living together more peacefully. However, there are still some wars within countries and terrorism has increased in recent years. Sadly, many more civilians than soldiers have died in wars since World War II. But even for civilians, the situation is not all bad. Although people are more likely to die from violent crime than from war, the number of murders worldwide has actually gone down. In 2000, about 8 people out of 100,000 were murdered, but by 2015, this number had decreased to about 5.3 people per 100,000.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Some news makes us think the world is becoming more violent. But there is also good news. From the end of World War II until 1990, there were 30 wars that killed over 100,000 people each. Today, there are still wars inside countries, but countries are living together in peace more often than before. However, terrorist attacks have become much more common in recent years. Also, since World War II, wars have killed many more ordinary people than soldiers. Even so, the numbers for ordinary people are not all bad. Violent crime is nine times more likely to cause death than wars between countries. But the number of murders around the world went down a little. In 2000, 8 people out of every 100,000 were murdered. By 2015, this number was about 5.3 people out of every 100,000.
gpt-oss-120b: News often says the world is getting more violent, but there is also some good news. Terrorism has increased a lot in the last few years, and since World War II wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even so, the numbers are not all bad. Deaths from violent crime are nine times more common than deaths from political conflict, but the global murder rate has fallen a little, from 8 people per 100,000 in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: When we see news about violence, it might seem like the world is getting more dangerous, but there’s some good news too. From the end of World War II until 1990, there were 30 wars that each killed more than 100,000 people. Today, there are still civil wars, but overall, countries are getting along more peacefully than before. However, terrorism has increased a lot in recent years, and since World War II, more civilians have been killed in wars than soldiers. Even so, the news for civilians isn’t all bad. While you’re nine times more likely to die from violent crime than from a conflict, the global murder rate has gone down slightly—from 8 deaths per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
mistral-medium-3:

However, terrorism has increased in recent years, and since World War II, wars have killed more civilians than soldiers.

But even for civilians, the news isn’t all bad. People are nine times more likely to die from violent crime than from war, but the number of murders around the world has gone down a little. In 2000, about 8 out of every 100,000 people were murdered. By 2015, that number dropped to about 5.3.
claude-sonnet-4: News stories often make us think the world is becoming more violent, but there are some good reasons to feel hopeful too. From the end of World War II until 1990, there were 30 wars where more than 100,000 people died. Today there are still wars inside countries, but most countries get along more peacefully than before. But terrorism has increased a lot in recent years. Also, since World War II, wars have killed many more ordinary people than soldiers. Even for ordinary people, the numbers are not all bad. People are nine times more likely to die from violent crime than from war, but the number of murders around the world went down a little - from 8 people per 100,000 in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
gemma-3-27b-it:
It can seem like the world is becoming more violent, but there is also some good news. After World War II, until 1990, there were 30 wars where over 100,000 people died in each one. Today, there are still wars in some countries, but generally, countries are getting along better than before.

However, there has been more terrorism recently. And since World War II, more ordinary people (civilians) have been killed in wars than soldiers. 

But even for ordinary people, things aren’t all bad. You are nine times more likely to die from a regular crime than from a war. Also, the number of murders around the world has slightly gone down – from 8 people out of every 100,000 in 2000, to about 5.3 in 2015.

**(Explanation of terms, not included in the simplification as requested, but for clarity: ‘civilians’ means ordinary people who are not soldiers. ‘terrorism’ means using violence to try to scare people or governments to get what they want.)**

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Wasfia has spent her life helping people have equal rights. She has seen many projects in her country to help women and girls, but often these projects stop and the women are left with nothing. Wasfia thinks Bangladesh should help itself, so she combined two things she loves: climbing mountains and human rights. She wants to change how people think about women in her country. Wasfia started climbing when she was working on projects in Tibet and Nepal. Most people in Bangladesh have never seen a mountain because it's a flat country near the sea. Now, people in her country and around the world are starting to pay attention to her campaign. She is making a difference and people are starting to care about women's rights.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507:
Wasfia has spent her life helping to protect human rights. She has seen many international aid projects in her home country, Bangladesh, that teach and train women and girls. But too often, when these projects end, the women are left with no support. Wasfia realized Bangladesh needed to make its own change. So she combined two things she loves: climbing mountains and fighting for human rights. She wanted to change how people in her country see women.

She first started climbing while working on aid work in Tibet and Nepal. In Bangladesh, a flat country near the sea, most people have never even seen a mountain. Now, her efforts are working. People in Bangladesh—and around the world—are starting to pay attention.

She first started climbing when she was working on help campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, because in a flat country by the sea like Bangladesh, most people have never seen a mountain. Her campaign seems to be working because people in her country and around the world are starting to pay attention.

Wasfia realised Bangladesh needed to help itself. So, she combined two things she loves – climbing mountains and helping people – to try and change how women are treated in her country. It looks like her work is helping. People in Bangladesh, and around the world, are starting to notice and listen.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Most people think that poor countries are in a very bad state: they are extremely poor, ruled by unfair leaders and have little chance of things getting better. But, surprisingly, this is not true. The truth is that big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, over 700 million people have earned more money and are no longer poor. Also, six million fewer children die from illnesses each year, more girls are going to school and many people now have clean water.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Most people think poor countries are in bad shape: full of extreme poverty, ruled by dictators, and with no real chance to improve. But surprisingly, that’s not true. In fact, big changes are happening. Over the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and moved out of poverty. Also, six million fewer children die each year from illness, many more girls now go to school, and millions of people can drink clean water.
gpt-oss-120b: Most people think that poor countries are in a very bad state: they have huge poverty (very little money), are ruled by dictators (leaders who do not allow freedom), and have little hope for change. But this is not true. In fact, big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and left poverty. Also, each year six million fewer children die from illness, many more girls go to school, and many people can get clean water.

Also, six million fewer children die each year from illnesses, and millions more girls go to school. Additionally, millions now have clean water.

Also, six million fewer children die every year from sickness, millions more girls go to school, and millions of people can now drink clean water.

Also, six million fewer children die each year because of illnesses. More girls are going to school, and millions more people can now get clean water to drink.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Some managers try to make their feedback sound better by saying something good, then something bad, and then something good again. But when they do this all the time, employees might think the good comments are just a way to make the bad news easier to hear. This means the good comments don't mean as much. Instead, managers should give good feedback to help employees do their jobs well, not just to make the bad news easier to hear.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Many managers try to make negative feedback feel better by putting it between two positive comments, like a sandwich. But when this happens too often, employees may start to see the positive comments as just a way to hide the negative ones. This makes the praise feel less meaningful. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften bad news. It should be given to truly support and encourage good work.
gpt-oss-120b: To add some good feeling to their comments, many managers put a negative comment between two positive ones. But when this is done all the time, workers may think the positive comments are just a way to hide the bad news, so they feel less useful. Instead, positive comments should not only be used to soften the negative; they should be given to support and encourage good work.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Many managers try to make their feedback more positive by placing negative comments between two positive ones. However, when this becomes a common practice, employees might start to see the positive comments as just a way to soften the negatives, making them less meaningful. Instead, positive feedback should be used to support and encourage good work, not just to cushion the negatives.
mistral-medium-3: Many managers try to make feedback more positive by putting negative comments between two good ones. But when this happens too often, workers might think the good comments are just there to make the bad ones seem better. This makes the good comments less meaningful. Instead, good feedback should not just be used to make bad feedback easier to take. It should be given to support and praise good work.
claude-sonnet-4: Many managers try to make negative feedback easier to hear by putting it between two positive comments. But when this becomes a normal habit, workers can start to think that positive feedback is just a way to make the bad news sound better. This makes the positive feedback less meaningful. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to make negative feedback softer. It should be given to support and encourage good work.
gemma-3-27b-it: Some managers try to make feedback easier to hear by starting and ending with positive comments around any criticism – like a sandwich. But if this happens often, people may think the positive comments aren’t sincere and don’t mean much. It’s better to give positive feedback to really show someone what they’re doing well and encourage them to keep it up, not just to soften bad news.
review:
Looking at each translation's strengths and weaknesses:

**Model LL**: Uses very simple language appropriate for A2 level. The structure is clear and easy to follow. However, it loses some precision from the original text and uses repetitive phrasing ("make the bad news easier to hear" appears twice).

**Model QW**: Maintains good clarity while preserving more of the original meaning. The sandwich metaphor is explicitly explained, which helps A2 learners. The vocabulary is appropriate and the message remains complete and accurate.

**Model GP**: Contains a significant error - states managers put "a negative comment between two positive ones" when it should be the reverse. This fundamental misunderstanding of the concept is a major weakness, though the language level is appropriate.

**Model DE**: Uses clear, accessible language while maintaining accuracy. The structure follows the original well and all key concepts are preserved. The vocabulary choices are suitable for A2 level.

**Model MI**: Uses simple vocabulary and clear structure. Maintains the core message accurately. The language is very accessible for A2 learners, though slightly less sophisticated than some other versions.

**Model CL**: Provides clear explanations and maintains accuracy. Uses appropriate A2 vocabulary and structure. The flow is logical and easy to follow.

**Model GE**: Explains the sandwich concept clearly and uses accessible language. However, it's slightly more complex in structure and introduces the concept of sincerity, which adds interpretation not explicitly in the original.

**Model RE**: Contains only nonsensical text ("Blah blah blah") followed by a ranking, making it completely unusable as a translation.

**Model WI**: Provides only a model name with no translation content, making it unusable.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct:
I'm part of a group that wants to stop killer robots. You might think of a movie robot that kills people, but this is real: the military is already using machines like drones and robots with guns to kill people with very little help from humans. Soon, we will have robots that can decide who to kill on their own. I think this is very wrong and dangerous for people. We need to be very careful about what we tell machines to do. 

Note: "autonomous" is not a simple word, but it's necessary to explain the idea. It means the robots can work and make decisions without humans controlling them. In this case, it's used as "decide who to kill on their own" to simplify the concept. "Unethical" is also not a simple word, but it's explained as "very wrong" to keep the original tone and meaning.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: I belong to the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the scary robot from movies that crushes skulls. Think about what’s happening now: military machines like drones, automatic guns, and guard robots are already being used to kill people, and humans don’t have to do much. The next step could be fully independent “killer robots” that follow orders but choose their own targets — deciding who to kill without human help. To me, this seems totally wrong and dangerous for people. We must be very careful about letting machines make life-or-death choices.
gpt-oss-120b:
I am a member of a group that wants to stop killer robots.  
Don’t think of the scary movie robot that steps on heads. Look at what is happening now: the army uses machines such as drones, gun turrets and guard robots to kill, and people control them only a little.  

The next step could be robots that work by themselves – “autonomous” means they decide what to do without a person. These “murderbots” would follow orders but would choose who to kill on their own.  

I think this is very wrong and very dangerous for people. We must be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

Look at what is happening now: military machines like drones, gun turrets, and sentry robots are already being used to kill with almost no human control. The next step will be self-controlled killer robots that follow orders but decide who to kill on their own. This seems very wrong and dangerous for humanity. We must be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

Think about what’s happening now: machines like drones and robot guns are already killing people with almost no human control. Soon, there could be robots that make their own decisions about who to kill. This seems very wrong and dangerous for all of us. We must be extremely careful about what we let machines do.

The next step will be robots that work alone and can decide who to kill by themselves. I think this would be very wrong and dangerous for all people. We need to be very careful about what we tell machines to do.

The army is already using machines like drones, and robots that can shoot guns, with not many people controlling them. Soon, we might have robots that can decide *on their own* who to kill, after getting orders. I think this is very wrong and could be really dangerous for people. We need to be careful about what we let machines do. 

**(Explanation of ‘drones’: machines that fly without a pilot inside, often used by the army)**

original: Overall, more people are learning English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.

The number of native speakers does not seem to affect how many people learn a language, but the number of countries where a language is spoken does seem to influence this.

But there is a clearer link between how many people are learning a language and how many countries have people who speak it.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Your boss stops you and says she wants to talk to you about your work on the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. When you go into her office on Monday morning, she starts by saying you did a good job on the project. You wonder if she's just being nice before telling you something bad. You know how these conversations usually go: your boss says something good, then something bad, then something good again. This is sometimes called a "feedback sandwich". It's when someone gives you some praise, then tells you what you did wrong, and then gives you some more praise.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Your boss stops you and says she wants to talk about how you did on the recent project. You spend the whole weekend worried, thinking about what you might have done wrong. On Monday morning, when you go into her office, she starts by saying good things about your work. Now you’re wondering: is this just the usual nice comment that comes before criticism? You know the pattern: start with something positive, then say what you really want to say (usually the hard part), and end with something nice again. It’s often called the “feedback sandwich.”
gpt-oss-120b: Your manager stops you and says she wants to talk about how you worked on the recent project. You think about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you go into her office on Monday morning, she starts by saying good things about the work you did on the project. You wonder if this is the usual polite praise that begins a “feedback sandwich.” A feedback sandwich is a way of giving comments: first say something nice, then say the real point you want to make, and finish with another nice comment.

On Monday morning, you go to her office. She starts by telling you that you did a good job on the project. You wonder if this is just the nice part before she tells you something you did wrong, like the usual 'feedback sandwich'. You know how that works: say something nice, say what you really want to say, then say something nice again.
mistral-medium-3: Your boss stops you and says she wants to talk about how you did on the last project. You spend the whole weekend worrying, thinking about what you might have done wrong. When you go into her office on Monday morning, she starts by saying you did a good job on the project. You wonder if this is just the nice part before the bad news, like in a "feedback sandwich." You know how it works—say something good, then say what’s really on your mind, then say something good again.
claude-sonnet-4: Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk about your work on the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. When you go into her office on Monday morning, she starts by saying good things about your work on the project. You think this might be the usual way managers give feedback. You know how this works: first they say something nice, then they say what they really think, then they say something nice again.
gemma-3-27b-it: Your boss wants to talk to you about how you did on the last project. You feel worried all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. On Monday morning, when you go to her office, she starts by saying good things about your work. You think this might be just the beginning of a talk where she’ll give you some criticism – a “feedback sandwich”. A feedback sandwich is when someone tells you something good, then tells you what you need to improve, and then finishes with something good again.
review:
Looking at each translation's strengths and weaknesses:

**Model LL**: Uses simple vocabulary and clear sentence structure appropriate for A2 level. Provides a clear explanation of "feedback sandwich" at the end. However, the explanation feels somewhat repetitive and could be more concise.

**Model QW**: Maintains good narrative flow and uses accessible language. Effectively conveys the emotional tension and includes the "feedback sandwich" concept naturally. Some phrases like "the hard part" add helpful clarification for A2 learners.

**Model DE**: Very simple language that fits A2 level well. The sentence "You worry all weekend, thinking you did something wrong" is particularly clear. However, it's quite brief and loses some of the original's detail about the weekend worry.

**Model MI**: Good use of simple vocabulary and maintains the story's emotional arc. The phrase "what's really on your mind" is accessible. Uses an em dash which might be slightly advanced for A2 but still comprehensible.

**Model CL**: Simple, clear language throughout. However, it omits the specific term "feedback sandwich" and provides a less detailed explanation of the concept, which reduces its educational value.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: This rock album, Born in the USA, is fast and fun to listen to. But the words in the songs are also very emotional. The catchy tunes hide stories about the tough side of life in America. Many songs are about ordinary people who work hard but are not happy because they don't have a lot of money or success. For example, the song Glory Days is about people who look back at their happy times when they were young. Another song, Downbound Train, is about a young man who loses his job and his life falls apart. You can tell that the singer is singing about real people and problems he knows about. This album shows how talented the singer, known as the Boss, really is.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507:
Born in the USA is a fast, lively rock album with songs that are fun to listen to and easy to move to. But behind the upbeat music, the words tell serious and emotional stories. The songs talk about the hard times many regular people face, even when they work hard. They feel disappointed and angry because life doesn’t give them success or happiness.

For example, the song "Glory Days" is about people from a small town remembering when they were young and full of hope. "Downbound Train" tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job.

It feels like the singer is singing about real people he knew, or even about the life he could have had if he hadn’t become famous. This album shows how special and talented the Boss — Bruce Springsteen — really is.

Behind the fun rock tunes are stories about the sad side of the “American dream” – the idea that anyone can become successful. Many songs talk about hard‑working ordinary people and the hurt and anger they feel when life does not give them money or fame.  

The song *Glory Days* is about people in a small town remembering when they were young and felt they could do anything. The song *Downbound Train* tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job.  

It is easy to think that the singer is using real people he knew and the life he might have had if he had not become a star. The album clearly shows the special and great talent of the Boss (Bruce Springsteen).

For example, "Glory Days" is about people in a small town remembering when they were young and full of hope. "Downbound Train" tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart when he loses his job. It feels like the singer is talking about real people he knew or a life he might have had if he wasn’t famous. This album clearly shows how talented the singer is.

They feel angry and upset because life doesn’t give them money or fame.

For example, the song *Glory Days* is about people in a small town remembering when they were young and full of hope. *Downbound Train* tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job. The song Glory Days is about people in a small town who remember when they were young and everything seemed possible. Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life goes wrong when he loses his job. You can imagine that the singer is thinking about real people he knew and the life he could have had if he didn't become famous. The album shows you how special and amazing the Boss really is.

Born in the USA is a lively rock album that makes you want to move. But the songs also have a lot of feeling. Even though the music is upbeat, the lyrics tell stories about difficult times in America.

Many songs are about normal people who work hard but still struggle. They feel upset and angry because life isn’t easy and they don’t become rich or famous. For example, “Glory Days” is about people remembering when they were young and felt like anything was possible. “Downbound Train” is about a young man whose life goes wrong when he loses his job.

review:
Looking at each translation's adherence to A2 level requirements and accuracy:

**Model LL**: Uses simple vocabulary and sentence structures appropriate for A2. Maintains all key information from the original text. The phrase "hide stories" effectively conveys the contrast between upbeat music and serious lyrics. Successfully explains both song examples and the artist's perspective.

**Model QW**: Provides clear explanations like "the hard times many regular people face" and includes helpful context by naming Bruce Springsteen. Uses appropriate A2 vocabulary throughout. Maintains the original meaning while making it accessible. Good balance of simplification without losing content.

**Model GP**: Uses some complex punctuation and explanatory phrases in parentheses that may be challenging for A2 learners. The phrase "the idea that anyone can become successful" adds helpful clarification. Includes all main points but the formatting with italics and em-dashes is inconsistent with A2 conventions.

**Model DE**: Omits the album title from the opening, which removes important context. Uses appropriate vocabulary but loses some specificity. The phrase "Under the catchy tunes" is slightly awkward. Covers all main themes but with less detail than other versions.

**Model MI**: Uses good A2-appropriate language and includes proper formatting with italics for song titles. The phrase "make you want to dance" effectively conveys the upbeat nature. Maintains all key information and explains concepts clearly.

**Model CL**: Uses very simple language appropriate for A2 level. The phrase "everything seemed possible" effectively captures the original meaning. Maintains all essential information while using accessible vocabulary throughout.

**Model GE**: Provides clear explanations and names Bruce Springsteen with his nickname. Uses appropriate A2 vocabulary. The phrase "felt like anything was possible" captures the original meaning well. Includes all main points with good clarity.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Lewis wants more areas in the ocean to be protected. Right now, only 3% of the ocean is safe. He wants this to increase to 10%. He thinks this will help fix the damage people have done to the ocean through actions like taking too many fish, putting bad things in the water, and throwing trash in the sea. Lewis has seen this damage himself when he swims in the ocean. He has swum over coral reefs that are dying because the water is too hot. He has also seen empty areas under the water in the Red Sea with a lot of plastic and no living things. Lewis believes that nature can get better if we give it space. But time is running out. If we don't start taking care of our oceans, we will soon have a big problem that we can't solve.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Lewis wants the world to protect more of its oceans. Right now, only 3 out of every 100 parts of the ocean are protected. He wants that number to grow to 10 out of 100. This would help fix the harm people have caused by catching too many fish, polluting, and leaving trash behind. On his trips, Lewis has seen this damage with his own eyes. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because the water is getting warmer. In the Red Sea, he’s seen areas that should be full of life but are now empty, like underwater deserts, covered in plastic. Lewis believes nature can heal if we give it a chance, but we don’t have much time. If we don’t start taking better care of our oceans soon, the problems could become too big to fix.
gpt-oss-120b: Lewis wants the number of protected places in the ocean to grow from 3 % to 10 % so we can fix the damage caused by people, such as catching too many fish, making the water dirty, and throwing trash. During his trips, Lewis has seen this damage himself. He has swum over coral reefs (big underwater rocks made of tiny animals) that have turned white because the water is getting hotter, and he has seen empty underwater areas in the shallow Red Sea that have no living things and are full of plastic. Pugh thinks nature can get better if we give it space, but time is running out. If we do not start caring for our seas, we may soon have a problem we cannot fix.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Lewis wants more protected areas in the ocean to increase from 3% to 10% to fix the harm caused by overfishing, pollution, and litter. On his trips, Lewis has seen this environmental damage up close. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because the water is warmer. He has also seen empty, lifeless areas under the Red Sea, filled with plastic. Lewis thinks nature can heal if we give it space, but time is running out. If we don't start taking care of our oceans, we will have a big problem soon.

On his trips, Lewis has seen this damage himself. He has swum over coral reefs that are white because the water is too warm. He has also seen empty areas under the Red Sea with no life, just plastic trash.

Lewis believes nature can heal if we give it space, but we must act fast. If we don’t take care of the seas now, the problem could become too big to solve.

People have hurt the seas by catching too many fish, making the water dirty, and throwing rubbish into it. During his trips, Lewis has seen this damage with his own eyes. He has swum over coral reefs that have lost their color because the water got too warm. Coral reefs are like underwater gardens where many sea animals live. He has also seen underwater areas in the Red Sea that look like empty deserts. There are no fish or plants there - only plastic rubbish. Pugh thinks that nature can get better if we give it space and time. But we need to act fast. If we don't start taking care of our seas now, we may soon have a problem that we cannot fix.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Lewis wants more areas in the ocean to be protected – he’d like to see this increase from 3% to 10%. He hopes this will help fix the harm people have caused, like catching too many fish, making the water dirty, and dropping rubbish.

Lewis has seen this damage himself when he’s been exploring. He’s swum over coral reefs that have turned white because the water is getting warmer. He’s also seen parts of the Red Sea where there are hardly any fish or plants, just plastic. 

Lewis thinks nature can get better if we let it, but we don’t have much time. If we don’t start taking care of our seas, we will have a very big problem that we can’t fix.

**(Explanation of terms, not included in the answer as requested):**

* **Marine protected areas:** Areas in the ocean where rules are in place to protect plants and animals.
* **Coral reefs:** Underwater structures made of coral, where many sea creatures live.
* **Bleached:** When coral turns white because of changes in the water, often caused by warmer temperatures. It means the coral is stressed and can die.
* **Polluting:** Making the water dirty and unsafe.
* **Expeditions:** Long journeys to explore a place.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Uses simple vocabulary and clear sentence structure appropriate for A2 level. Explains concepts like "taking too many fish" instead of "overfishing." Maintains the main message and urgency of the original text.
Weaknesses: Uses "putting bad things in the water" which is vague. The phrase "empty areas under the water" could be clearer.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Effectively explains percentages with "3 out of every 100 parts" which aids A2 comprehension. Uses clear, simple vocabulary throughout. Maintains the metaphor of "underwater deserts" while making it accessible.
Weaknesses: Slightly longer sentences that may challenge A2 readers. Some phrases like "leaving trash behind" could be more direct.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Provides helpful explanations in parentheses for "coral reefs." Uses simple vocabulary and maintains key information. Clear cause-and-effect relationships.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Are things getting worse every day? Is it impossible to make the world a better place? In his book "Enlightenment Now", Steven Pinker looks at how humanity is doing and finds some good news. We are living longer, healthier, and happier lives. We are also more free. The real problem, Pinker says, is that people are questioning some important ideas from the past, like using reason and science to make decisions. When some leaders and commentators try to make people think only about their own group and not about the future, we are in danger of hurting important things like democracy and working together as countries.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible? In *Enlightenment Now*, Steven Pinker looks at the overall picture of human progress and finds good news. We live longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives than before. The real problem, Pinker says, is that the values of reason and science from the Enlightenment are under threat. When leaders and media appeal to people’s tribal feelings, fear, and distrust, we risk harming important systems like democracy and global cooperation.
gpt-oss-120b: Are things getting worse each day? Is making progress impossible? In the book *Enlightenment Now*, Steven Pinker looks at the whole story of human progress and finds good news. We now live longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. Pinker says the real problem is that the ideas of the Enlightenment – using reason (thinking carefully) and science – are being attacked. When speakers and leaders use people’s strong loyalty to their own group, a belief that nothing can change, and mistrust, we risk hurting important systems such as democracy and international cooperation in a way that cannot be fixed.

When some leaders and commentators appeal to people’s tribalism, fatalism, and distrust, we risk badly harming important things like democracy and global cooperation.

The real problem, Pinker says, is that the ideas of reason and science from the Enlightenment are being attacked. When leaders and loud voices use fear, hopelessness, and distrust to divide people, they put important things like democracy and global teamwork at risk.

The real problem, Pinker says, is that important ideas about using reason and science are being attacked. Pinker thinks the real problem is that people are not trusting in reason (thinking carefully) and science (studying the world around us) as much as they should. When leaders and people in the media try to make people feel like they only belong with their own group, or that nothing can be changed, or that we shouldn’t trust others, then important things like democracy (a system where people choose their leaders) and countries working together could be harmed badly.
review:
Looking at each translation's adaptation to CEFR A2 level:

**Model LL**: Maintains the original structure well and simplifies complex terms appropriately. Uses clear explanations like "make people think only about their own group" for tribalism. However, some phrases like "questioning some important ideas from the past" could be clearer, and "irreparable damage" is simplified to just "hurting" which loses some meaning precision.

**Model QW**: Preserves the original meaning closely while using simpler vocabulary. Effectively translates "tribalism" to "tribal feelings" and maintains the flow. The phrase "under threat" might be slightly advanced for A2, and some technical terms remain unchanged.

**Model GP**: Provides helpful clarifications in parentheses like "(thinking carefully)" for reason. Good simplification of complex concepts. However, the explanation "in a way that cannot be fixed" is somewhat wordy, and the overall sentence structure becomes quite long in places.

**Model DE**: Offers a clean, concise adaptation that maintains the core message. Simplifies "every day" to just the concept without the frequency. Some terms like "fatalism" are removed rather than explained, which loses content but improves readability.

**Model MI**: Uses accessible language like "loud voices" and "global teamwork." Good simplification of abstract concepts. However, "fear, hopelessness, and distrust" doesn't fully capture the original terms (tribalism, fatalism, distrust), changing the meaning somewhat.

**Model CL**: Provides detailed explanations and context. Uses very simple language throughout. However, becomes quite verbose with explanations like "people who talk on TV and political leaders," which may be too lengthy for the level.

**Model GE**: Includes extensive parenthetical explanations for complex terms. Very thorough in making concepts accessible. However, the explanations make sentences extremely long and potentially confusing, and some explanations are overly basic for A2 level.

**Model RE**: Does not provide a translation, only produces nonsensical text.

**Model WI**: Does not provide a translation, only shows a model identifier.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.

So, how do filmmakers keep the story exciting? They often say there's no phone signal! If you're the main character in a scary movie, you can be sure that when you really need to call for help, your phone won't work. Either there's no signal, or your battery will run out just as you're making the call. It's very frustrating!

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their best banana, called Gros Michel or Big Mike, was dying. Now it's happening again to the Cavendish banana, which replaced Big Mike. The Gros Michel banana was very popular because it was easy to transport, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. It was the main banana grown on farms in Central America. A big company called United Fruit grew and exported most of the bananas in South America at that time. They grew bananas in a special way: they took small parts from the stems of plants and made new plants, instead of growing them from seeds. They planted many bananas close together in the fields.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were losing their most profitable banana, the Gros Michel, also called Big Mike. Now the same thing is happening to the banana that replaced it – the Cavendish. The Gros Michel banana was very popular because the fruit was sweet, had thick skin, and was easy to ship. To grow more bananas quickly, the main company, United Fruit, did not use seeds. Instead, they used pieces from the stems of plants to make new ones – this is called cloning. They planted these banana plants close together in large fields.

United Fruit, the biggest banana grower and seller in South America at that time, made many bananas quickly: it copied small new shoots from the plant stems instead of planting seeds, and grew them close together in the field.

These plants were everywhere in Central America's plantations. United Fruit, the biggest grower and exporter in South America at that time, produced bananas in large quantities. The Gros Michel banana was very popular because it was easy to transport, had thick skin, and tasted sweet. It grew on many farms in Central America. They made bananas in a fast way: instead of growing new plants from seeds, they took parts from old plants and grew them in big, crowded fields.

It was easy to transport because it had thick skin, and it tasted sweet. This banana plant was the most popular one in Central America. United Fruit was the biggest company that grew and sold bananas in South America at that time. They wanted to make as many bananas as possible in the easiest way. So they did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they took small parts from banana plant stems and made copies of the same plant. They put these plants very close together in big fields.

‘Big Mike’ was a great banana because it was easy to move around, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. It grew on most banana farms in Central America. A big company called United Fruit grew and sold most of the bananas at that time. They found a quick way to grow lots of bananas: they made new plants from parts of existing plants, instead of using seeds. They grew the plants very close together in fields.

**Model MI**: Uses very simple language appropriate for A2. Explains the process clearly as "took parts from old plants." Good use of descriptive language like "big, crowded fields." Contains all key information in an accessible format.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Most spiders have venom, but they use it to catch their prey, not to attack people. In fact, only a few types of spiders can hurt humans with their venom. Their bites can be painful, but they are rarely fatal. There is a famous spider in Australia called the Sydney funnel-web spider. It's very poisonous, but nobody has died from its bite since doctors found a cure in 1981. However, be careful with big, hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel scared, they can release a cloud of tiny, annoying hairs. These hairs can get stuck in your skin or eyes and cause irritation.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Most spiders have venom, but they use it to catch prey, not to attack people. Only 25 kinds of spiders have venom strong enough to hurt humans, and even then, bites are usually painful but not deadly. For example, Australia’s dangerous Sydney funnel-web spider has caused no deaths since the anti-venom was made in 1981. But be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they can flick tiny, irritating hairs from their body. These hairs can get into your skin or eyes and cause discomfort.

Be careful when you handle hairy spiders such as tarantulas. If they think they are in danger, they spray a cloud of tiny irritating hairs. These hairs can get into the skin or eyes of the person who touches them.

But be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. Don't make them angry. When they feel scared, they shoot out special hairs that cause pain and itching. gemma-3-27b-it:

In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider used to be very dangerous, but no one has died from its bite since they made an antivenom in 1981. Antivenom is a medicine that stops venom from hurting you.

Be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel scared, they will shoot out tiny hairs that can cause itching and irritation. These hairs can get in your skin or eyes.
review:

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.

It's not just about the size of our brains, but also what they can do and how they developed over time. Unfortunately, we don't have many physical signs to help us, like old tools or objects, that can tell us what kind of speech our ancestors were able to make. However, when we look at the remains of early humans, we can see how their mouths, throats, and tongues changed. About 100,000 years ago, humans developed the ability to make complicated sounds. Before that, we can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: To understand where our ability for complex language comes from, we need to look at how our brains are different from those of other animals. original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: It's the way our society is, not how we are born, that makes people think girls should like arts and humanities, and boys should like maths and physics. Also, young people don't see many women doing jobs related to science. In cartoons and stories, the person who invents things or goes to space is usually a man. Many people think scientists are strange, don't have friends, and work alone. This is not true, but people see it on TV and in movies. This means girls might not want to be scientists because they don't see themselves in that role. If girls saw more women scientists who are happy and successful, they would feel more confident and want to study science too.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: It is society, not nature, that says girls should prefer arts and humanities, while boys do maths and science. Also, young people rarely see women working in science. These are wrong ideas spread by the media, but they can make girls feel science is not for them and not a good career choice. If girls saw more women doing science, they would feel more confident and more connected to these subjects.

Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, the clever inventor, or the brave astronaut as a man. Also, many people think scientists are nerdy, have bad social skills, or work alone and far from everyday life. These are wrong ideas shown by the media, but they can make girls feel they do not fit with scientists and think science is not a good job. If girls saw more good female role models in science, they would feel more sure of themselves and feel they belong in those subjects.

If girls saw more women in science doing great things, they would feel more confident and belong more in these subjects.

These ideas are not true, but they come from TV and movies. Because of this, girls don't want to be scientists. gemma-3-27b-it:
It’s not natural for girls to prefer subjects like art and literature – society teaches them to. People often think boys are better at subjects like maths and science. Also, young people don’t often see women working in science jobs.

These ideas aren’t true, and the media often shows them this way. But these ideas might make girls think science isn’t for them, and they might not want to be scientists.

If girls had more examples of successful women in science, they would feel more confident and like they belong in those subjects.

Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.

review:
I'll analyze each translation for A2 level appropriateness, accuracy, and clarity.

**Model LL**: Uses simple fraction format "12 out of 100" which is very accessible for A2 learners. The sentence structure is clear and straightforward. However, it oversimplifies "employee engagement" to just "not happy with their jobs," missing the nuance of the original concept.

**Model QW**: Provides good explanation with "12 out of every 100" and includes helpful context about industry comparison. The phrase "feel connected—or not connected—to their work" is a good A2-level explanation of engagement. The translation is comprehensive and maintains most original meaning while being accessible.

**Model GP**: Very concise and uses percentage format which may be harder for some A2 learners. The phrase "feel involved in the company" adequately captures employee engagement. However, it's quite brief and loses some explanatory detail that would help A2 comprehension.

**Model DE**: Uses percentage format and maintains formal tone. However, it contains a significant error by stating the report aims to find out "why employees stay engaged" when the original discusses investigating causes of engagement issues (implying disengagement). This changes the meaning substantially.

**Model MI**: Provides clear explanation with good A2 vocabulary. Uses percentage format but explains the comparison well. The phrase "not happy or involved in their jobs" effectively conveys the engagement concept. The structure is logical and easy to follow.

**Model CL**: Uses the accessible "12 people out of every 100" format and provides good industry context with "food companies." The explanation is thorough and uses simple vocabulary throughout. Maintains the original meaning while being very accessible to A2 learners.

**Model GE**: Includes helpful definitions of "turnover" and "retention" in parentheses, which is valuable for A2 learners. However, it has a formatting error with the period placement and focuses more on why workers are leaving rather than investigating engagement causes.

**Model RE**: Contains only nonsensical text "Blah blah blah" followed by a ranking, making it completely unusable.

**Model WI**: Contains only a model identifier with no translation content.

But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. review:
I'll analyze each translation's strengths and weaknesses for CEFR A2 level appropriateness:

**Model LL:**
Strengths: Uses simple, clear language appropriate for A2 level. Maintains the main ideas while simplifying complex concepts.
Weaknesses: Loses some nuance from the original, particularly the idiomatic expression "another kettle of fish" is completely omitted rather than simplified.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Preserves most key ideas while using A2-appropriate vocabulary. Good balance between simplification and content retention. Maintains logical flow.
Weaknesses: Some phrases like "miss out on learning" might be slightly above A2 level.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Uses very simple sentence structures suitable for A2. Clear and direct language.
Weaknesses: Some awkward phrasing like "people younger than 20" and "different case." The phrase "the ability to talk" is somewhat unnatural.

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Very concise and uses simple vocabulary throughout. Easy to understand for A2 learners.
Weaknesses: Significantly shortened, losing important details about the generational comparison and the editing aspect of digital communication.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Maintains good content coverage while using appropriate A2 vocabulary. Clear structure and logical progression.
Weaknesses: Some phrases like "I really agree with" could be simpler. Minor redundancy in explanations.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Preserves most original meaning while simplifying language. Good use of connecting words appropriate for A2.
Weaknesses: The phrase "completely different" adds emphasis not in the original. Some sentences are slightly long for A2.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Very clear explanation of the digital communication concept. Good use of simple present tense throughout.
Weaknesses: The final sentence about thinking quickly is somewhat complex for A2. Some repetitive phrasing.

**Model RE:**
This appears to be incomplete or corrupted output, not a proper translation.

This is not a translation but appears to be a model identifier.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: When you give good feedback, don't always give bad feedback at the same time. If you always do this, people might not care about the good feedback. Sometimes, just give good feedback because it's good. Don't feel like you have to say something bad as well. This means "constructive criticism" - it's when you tell someone how they can improve. Try not to do this every time you say something good.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Don't always give negative feedback after positive feedback. If they always come together, people might start ignoring the good comments. Sometimes, just give praise on its own and avoid adding criticism.
gpt-oss-120b: Don’t always give a negative comment after a positive one. If you always mix good and bad comments, the good ones can seem less important and be ignored. Make sure you sometimes give good comments just because they are good, and try not to feel the urge to add helpful criticism.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Don't always give positive comments followed by negative ones. If you always mix positive and negative comments, people might start ignoring the positive ones. Sometimes, just give positive comments without adding anything else. Try not to always include suggestions for improvement.
mistral-medium-3: Don’t always give negative feedback right after positive feedback. If you always mix good and bad comments together, the good ones might seem less important and get ignored. Sometimes, just give praise without adding any criticism. Try not to always point out what could be better.
claude-sonnet-4: Don't always give bad feedback after good feedback. When good and bad feedback always come together, people stop believing the good things you say. Make sure you sometimes give good feedback by itself. Don't always feel you need to add things that need to be better.
gemma-3-27b-it: Don’t always say something good and then something bad. If you always give a good comment followed by a bad one, people might stop noticing the good things. Make sure to sometimes say something good without needing to also say something to improve. Try not to always point out what someone could do better.
